reviewText: This is a very nice water resistant speaker. It has a white plastic shell and has a few colored rubber parts. I chose a green one and it looks superb. I use this speaker when I'm in the shower and it works great. It has gotten wet many many times and has not short circuited. I have not completely submerged it because it's only water resistant, not water proof. It's surprisingly loud for such a small speaker. You can take calls with it but I don't think I will be taking calls while I'm in the shower. The suction cup on it is extremely useful and sticks onto a lot of surfaces in my bathroom. It's a great speaker that I would definitely get for a friend or relative. I received this product as a review sample.

Out of the box, it took 30 minutes to charge the built-in lithium battery using the included USB cable. The User Manual is clear and brief with logical steps detailed to pair the speaker with phone or other Bluetooth capable devices like an iPod, iPad, etc. A short press of the plus or minus sign increases or decreases volume, while a long press either moves the song selection forward or back. A clicking noise is heard to alert the user when maximum volume is reached.  Pressing the phone icon button permits incoming calls to be answered.For a small speaker the performance is surprisingly good. Optimal sound resides in the upper and mid range with bass a bit weak -- with nothing sounding distorted even at maximum volume. The speaker works up to thirty feet from the device to which it is paired, and will run for four hours per battery charge. While in the shower, I tested it both with my phone and iPod and the sound was clear even above the noise of the water running, and I could easily carry on a conversation with the caller, although they thought it was weird when I told them I was speaking from the shower.The speaker has a large suction cup on the back which I stuck to the shower wall, out of the direct path, but next to the water stream. Water was definitely splashed on the device the entire time I was in the shower. It adhered securely, and stayed firmly attached to the tile even while control buttons were pushed multiple times. The silicone face of the unit provided a relatively non-slip texture when wet so no undue pressure was necessary to change songs or adjust volume.Water resistant with an IPX4 rating, which means the speaker should be able to withstand being splashed from all angles for at least five minutes but it should not be submerged in water. As I noted above, it was splashed on for a good ten minutes while I tested the music and phone capabilities without any problems.Small, attractive, and it did everything it promised.Sample provided without obligation.
summary: AQUACUBE - URGE Basics Water Resistant Shower Speaker

reviewText: Over the past year I have reviewed nearly a dozen waterproof bluetooth speakers and all seemed to fall short in one or more categories. The review sample that I received for this one is actually a vast improvement over the other ones.The biggest reason I like this one is you can actually hear it in a shower. The other ones I have tried sounded good on their own, but the minute you turned on a shower that noise drowned out the music I was trying to play. This one is loud enough to cut through that,Another feature that this has that the older ones lacked is it goes into pairing more as soon as you power it up. In fact, a female voice announces the fact. All of the other waterproof speakers I have tried required you to hold down a multifunction button for a set number of seconds, then scan for it from your phone. This one is so simple to pair with and connect to that you do not need the instruction sheet that comes with it.One final thing that distinguishes this one from the others is the large suction cup that will hold it firmly to a tiled (or any smooth) surface. Believe me, it will hold the speaker like glue.Music quality is surprisingly good. The speaker's frequency response across the high, low and mid ranges did an excellent job of playing my favorite test album (Miles Davis'Kind Of Blue) and I could hear every nuance. Considering that this speaker is encased in sound deadening rubber makes me wonder how much better it would sound in a non-waterproof form factor.At the time of this review the product description on this page claims that you can get four hours of play time on a completely charged speaker. The instructions claim ten, and I've had mine running for nearly six hours as I write this review and it's still going strong. It takes about three hours to fully charge it out of the box.Bottom line: this waterproof speaker is the only one that I've tested that I can recommend without reservations.
summary: Vast improvement over other waterproof BT speakers

reviewText: The Urge Basics Aquacube is smaller than a bathroom tile.  It has some candy charm (I have the white with lime green accent) by the way it looks.Pairing:Pairing is simple. Just turn it on and it will start looking for a device.  I didn't have to punch in a password but if it asked for one, type in "0000".The suction cup is very flexible and really sucks. I have no worries that it won't stay put.It comes with a microUSB cable for charging the Bluetooth player. The USB port is covered with a silicone plug to avoid getting wet.  LED is red when charging and disappears when fully charged.  All the other button controls are  sealed.Controls are simple like the - and + for volume. The middle button for pause and play.  Phone icon for answering calls and the power button symbol is on the top.  To go to the next song, you need to press and hold the + button until it the music stop and play the next song.  Same thing for - for previous.Finally the audio. Audio is loud and fine for a speaker of this type.  Don't expect much bass.  Also great to play NPR while in the shower.Cons:- Announcement (when you turn it on, pair, etc.) is scandalously loud.  On the other hand, this is an advantage if you are in the shower.  Too loud, if for some reason you want to play it in the office environment.- very little bassA sample of this product was sent to me for review purposes.

Place it in the shower and stream your tunes.  As we all know....we sound good in the shower.I however like this better on the boat.  Place it on the windshield and you have your own personal speaker.It really does have a good sound to it.  Since I got it for free for writing this review I decided to test it out.Recipe: Take one urge basics and drop it into one bag of fish. Leave it in water for a few minutes.  I took it out and did let it dry out for about half an hour.Place back on windshield.  Guess what.  It still worked.  So it is water resistant/repellant.  amazing little thing.
summary: Better sound that anticipated.  IS water resistant.

reviewText: I have been on a quest for a shower speaker, and I thought I had one in the past. It was labeled "water proof" when in fact it was also water resistant and they did not recommend it for shower use.When I opened this, I was surprised at the small size. Don't let the size fool you-- the sound is big! The sound projects out the back and uses the shower wall as an amplifier. It is quite surprising.It is very easy to use and in fact I didn't need to reference the instructions.  After charging I was able to pair and use it with no issues. There is a voice that tells you what's going on, and what to do when you are pairing to your phone. It also shows on my phone how much battery life is left in the unit.I would have no hesitations recommending this device, it works very well and I couldn't be more pleased.By a lot of hard hours and days and years of time spent reviewing, I found myself in the top 10 reviewers on Amazon. This wasn't a goal or self promotion, but by nose-down focused reviewing. I occasionally get contacted by manufacturers or sellers who appreciate my way of reviewing and ask if I'll consider reviewing a product for them, with no obligation or cost. This is one of those products. I assure you that I review what I want, when I want, how I want, in order to share what I feel is the most accurate useful information.

There are many of these portable batteries on the market now and I think I own most of them.  I have received several at no charge in exchange for my honest review, including this one. This is my second favorite.  It's good, but not the best.If you're going to get a portable battery, forget the "lipstick" models.  Make sure you get one that has a power gauge on it.  Since you are likely to use the device infrequently, you want to be able to check how much of a charge it has on it before you walk out the door. Once you've charged your device, you will want to know if you can get another charge out of it.  And, if you have a tablet, you're going to need a high capacity port (2A) and a decent size battery to charge it.  Don't waste your money on the smaller, lower capacity devices.The LifeCharge JuicyPack has everything you need to get the job done, with one exception I'll cover later.  It has a four light battery gauge so you can tell how much juice you have left within 25%.  It has two ports for charging your device and one port (micro USB) for charging it. It comes with a micro USB cable.  It includes a flashlight (because why not?).The reasons why it's my second favorite charger right now?  Well, one is the price. It's a bit expensive as this field has become competitive and prices have plummeted.  The battery light indicators are nice and were the standard.  That is until the one I just received that has an LED display that shows the exact percentage of battery left in a digital read out as opposed to a few lights.  That's not really necessary, but it is nice. The biggest reason this is number two for me is almost none of these devices come with a lightning connector, and I have an iPhone and an iPad. For me to use this, means I have to carry two cables with me- the micro USB cable to charge it and a lightning cable to charge my device.  One manufacturer has finally figured this out and includes a lightning cable with their unit.  If you're an Apple guy like me, I would recommend that one.  It's cheaper, the battery gauge is nicer and you don't need to carry two cables.  If you're not an Apple guy or gal, this one will certainly do, but you can probably find one for less money.  Overall, this is a nice product and could be a lifesaver in a tough spot.
summary: Pretty nice high capacity battery, but not the best

reviewText: I worked in the field and require power for all the devices I use. Sometimes, I'll be miles from any power source and need backup external batteries that I can depend on. The external battery packs by Lifecharge have never let me down. In addition their versatility is as important as they work with all my devices, from cameras, laptop, to iPhones. The 10400 is powerful enough for the most demanding devices.Tough, rugged, durable are just a few of the words I can use to describe the device besides delivering the power when I need it the most. As an Author and Indie film maker, it is critical to have these on hand when working in the field and can testify that the battery packs by Lifecharge deliver when it counts

This battery pack might be fit in your pocket, but big enough energy to power any mobile devices.Having a 10,400mAh battery places this battery pack in the upper range of battery packs. There is enough power to charge most cell phones multiple times. I use it to charge my Note 2 and get almost four full charges.The size is very portable and can be easily slipped into a pocket or purse.The layout is very clean and simple with no moving parts. The design is great with two complementing colors of blue and white. In the hand, it has a very solid feel, nice and sturdy. The size is similar to a deck of playing cards.This battery will do the job to charge whatever you throw at it, and does it well. The best part is how portable and powerful it is.I was supplied a sample for the purpose of review.

The bottom line on the LifeCHARGE battery is this: it works. In the past I've tried several different reserve power supplies for my gadgets, and I have had mixed results. However, there is no ambiguity about this battery: it's large, effective, versatile and well designed. It's one of the largest external battery that I've come across in terms of capacity (with impressive 10,400 mAh of charge), and yet it's much smaller in size than some of its larger near-competitors.In order to test this battery charger I decided to completely drain my small electronic devices so that I get as clean of an idea of this battery's efficiency as I can. (As an aside, when you really want to discharge them, the consumer electronics has become really robust in recent year. It took me much longer than I thought it would. I had to blast music from my iPhone for hours and hours ...) I discover that I was able to fully charge all of my small electronic devices with plenty of power to spare. Most of them I was able to charge several times, and thanks to dual USB ports, was able to charge up to two devices at once. Full charging usually takes between one to two hours. I've tested this battery with iPhone 4S, iPhone 3G, Kindle Keyboard, Mobee Magic Bar, Jabra SPORT Bluetooth Stereo Headset, and the first generation iPad (32GB, Wifi + 3G). Oftentimes I was able to fully charge four or five devices with just one fully charged LifeCHARGE battery. I was also able to charge my iPad to completely, and even charge it to almost half its capacity the second time around. If there was an easy way of connecting this battery to an ultrabook I would not be surprised if it would be possible to charge it to a decent amount as well.The battery comes with a micro USB cable that allows you to charge it by either connecting it to a computer or a stand-alone USB charger. I think this would have been a much more effective product if it had two additions that some of its competitors already incorporate into their batteries/power banks: incorporated wall-outlet prongs for easy charging, and a permanently attached retractable micro USB cable. These two additions would make this battery stand out in the already very crowded field of external batteries/chargers.**** Product provided for review purposes. ****
summary: Capacious, Elegant and Portable External Battery

reviewText: If you're like me, you don't pay too much attention to the measurements of things you buy. I'm a pretty smart guy, but when buying things like this, I usually just go by sight by looking at the provided photo. Sometimes this lack of investigating leads me to something too big (i.e. all-in-one printer), but here's what I found out when I received this: it's pretty small. Roughly the size of a pack of cigarettes, only slightly thinner. This is actually a good thing... no, a GREAT thing. For the most part, a battery really is just a battery, but if you can get one in a small package, then you're golden. And I am here to report that this one is small for its WHOPPING 10400 Mah capacity.I also like that it has LED indicators, which is helpful since I never remember which one of my packs is full.[sample provided for an honest review]

This battery charger / power bank has enough juice to re-charge several devices. So, if you are heading out and there's a chance that you won't see a wall outlet or car charger for quite a while, or if you are in "charge" of charging the whole family's devices on a trip, this is a charger that will get the job done. No bells, no whistles, except for a flashlight feature and four LEDs to give you charging status. But then, you are not paying for any features that you won't use, either.One feature that a 5-star, simple, convenient charger would have (and this four-star charger does not have) is a built-in USB cable. With this portable charger, you will still have to lug around a cable or two. Too bad: A rubber band does the trick and will keep your cables and charger together, but is so un-cool.This charger has four bright blue LEDs to give you status of the charge. Unlike aluminum-cased battery chargers, you can see the light of the LEDs right through this thin-walled plastic case, so more than the four lights light up: You get a blotchy light effect from inside the case.This unit weighs in at a little more than a half pound. So, think hard if you really need a power bank that provides this much charge. While it is necessary for long trips or lots of devices, if you only need to charge your one phone once in a while, this is overkill. Overkill is definitely a problem when it comes to chargers: A half pound is real weight. Do you need it? Or can you get by with a 2600mAh lipstick-size charger that will fit in your pocket and will charge up your one phone one time.For those of you who do not like in-your-face logos marring the fronts of your possessions: Notice that the Lifecharge logo is very big and bold and black and centered. It definitely detracts from the simple lines and the look of this design, and the black ink on the bright blue plastic cheapens the look.One thing I noticed that was interesting--and may be why different people get different test charge results: I charged it up the first time, until I got.the blue fully-charged light, then unplugged it, but did not use it. Plugged it in a few hours later, and it showed a red not-fully-charged light. So I left it plugged and in an hour it showed blue again. I unplugged it and did not use it.until the next day. I checked the charge, and it still showed blue. So, for some reason, when charging for the first time, it did not accept a 100% charge. The second time it did. I'm no electrical engineer, so I don't know why. It happened with the Lifecharge 2600mAh that I've been working with, too.*I received a sample product from Lifecharge.
summary: Basic, simple charger does what it claims to do

reviewText: This portable charger is the real deal.  It's businesslike, sturdy, and best of all, does exactly what it says it will.  I received a sample for review, but would not hesitate to purchase one.  Except for Vine products, I don't review samples unless they're great.This external battery is big.  It won't get lost in your carry on.  It takes about five hours to charge, so foresight is necessary, but it's good to go for at least a couple of complete charges.  I've used it with both my iPad and Kindle DX, and it took a couple of hours to charge from less than 20% to above 80%.  That's the same as using a wall plug.There are four blue lights that flash while the unit is charging.  As it charges, the lights stop flashing as quarter levels are reached.  In addition there are indicator lights to show when the devices being charged are powered up.  You always know how much juice is left in the charger, which is invaluable if you've every had one Odeon you without warning.You should know that the Lifecharge Juicypack does not come with a wall charger.  All that's in the box are the unit and a USB connector.  That's certainly not a problem for me--I could macrame a hammock out of all the superfluous cables around my house--but it's something you should know.A battery backup is essential if you're dependent on your electronic devices.  My experience with Lifecharge is that their products are well made and dependable.  This one is no exception.

This is a high powered external battery charger with 10400mAh and dual charging ports. I received this as a review sample. The two charging ports are 1.0A and 2.0A which means you can charge a large device and a small one or two small ones. It comes with your usual circuit protection that protects against over-charging and other damage to your device. It also has a small LED flashlight (dual beams). Overall, what I like about it is that it's small and handy and holds 10400mAh in capacity. With this much charging power you can charge your phone 3x over assuming a 75% efficiency rate and your iPad once. Recommended.

I have had absolutely no problems with my LifeCharge. I charged mine from the wall - I've got a wall charger that the usb cable comes with - it doesn't come with the wall charge component though - it would be very nice if it did. If you don't have a wall to usb plug, then you charge it using any usb port.It has 4 lights that each show 25%. When it is fully charged, they all light up.It charges a number of devices. I've been using it on my Kindle Fire, Apple I-phone 3gs, and my HTC One X. I like to binge watch tv while I work with my Kindle Fire propped in front of the PC. Using the LifeCharge, I was able to watch 10 straight hours of a TV show I was binging on without having to worry about running out of power. By the time I quit, the LifeCharge was empty but I STILL had a full charge on the Kindle, so I could have probably watched another couple of hours.Just make sure when you are ready to use a device, that you do turn the power ON. There's a little button on the side. It also has a LED flashlight that comes in handy.It's not heavy - it only weighs a few ounces, so it is fine to carry in my purse. The blue color is as shown. It's easy to hold; it fits well in my palm as it is narrow enough to grip ok.  It is wide, but the company also offers a lipstick size if this is a concern.My only complaint is rather minor - the blue indicator lights are VERY bright, so if you are charging it while sleeping, it can bug you. The first night I found I had to get up and position it with the lights against the wall. I made the mistake of looking right at those blue lights for a few seconds, and I got a bit of an after image for a while. I think they are too bright.It does charge well.  For instance, I had a bluetooth speaker that had 25% charge on it.  We wanted to watch a movie outside so I plugged my Juicypack into my speaker, and we watched 2 full movies and one tv series without the speaker ever going dead.  When I brought the speaker in, I noticed it still was nearly charged, though the Juicypack was depleted.I was given a sample in order to provide an honest review. I do like this product. It's nice to get so many more hours of charge time on my favorite device.
summary: Very convenient, with lots of extra play time on my devices

reviewText: This power bank has a large 10,400 mAh nominal capacity that will recharge most smartphones or Kindle Paperwhites five or six times and provide almost a complete recharge to a power-hungry tablet like the 8,820 mAh iPad Air.  It has two charging ports, one each at 2.1 A and 1.0 A, to quickly charge two electronic devices at the same time.There is a four-LED indicator for charging and remaining capacity.  It also has a handy dual-LED flashlight that is quite bright, very useful in emergencies or just for finding a dropped key in the dark.  A good quality USB cable and legible instruction manual are also included.I suggest using a USB wall adapter or a charging hub to refill this power bank because of the large capacity, as it will be much faster than most all USB ports on electronic devices.LifeCHARGE provided a Juicypack for evaluation and review.

There are some excellent reviews already posted that completely describe this battery. I will avoid repeating the physical characteristics and provide my own observations and experiences with the review sample that I received.This battery pack has the capacity to satisfy most power users who are glued to their phone. It will also provide a respectable margin of additional use time for the true geeks who are constantly glued to both a smart phone and a tablet. For that breed of power user even the 10400mAh capacity this provides may not be enough, but for ninety-nine percent of us this is more than ample.Before proceeding I want to disclose that I always multiply new battery packs by .9 to get a more realistic capacity. That's because there are some losses in efficiency from heat, the transfer process, condition of your charging cable and myriad other factors. Using my quick formula you can expect about 9360mAh from this battery.Even at the readjusted capacity you can expect some significant increases in use time. An Apple iPhone 5S with a stock 1560mAh battery will get an additional six hundred percent of use time attached to this. An iPad 2 with a stock 6930mAh battery will get slightly more than double its normal use time. Of course plugging two devices into this battery will alter the effective use time increases, but some very simple math will let you forecast how much.I tested this with a few devices, including an iPhone 5S, iPad 2, Samsung Galaxy Note 3 and Samsung Tab 3 10.1. In all cases I connected two devices simultaneously (Apples first, then the Samsungs) and the charging rate from this battery was slightly less than if I plugged each device individually into their respective OEM wall chargers. That's actually pretty impressive.Note that the instructions claim that you can charge this battery from a PC's USB port. I tried that on my ThinkPad T61 and it was extremely show compared to one of my Samsung wall chargers to which I connected it. This is more of a problem with my ThinkPad than the battery, but I wanted to point that out to set expectations.Bottom line: this battery pack is solid, reliable and has more than enough capacity for all but true power users. Mine is actually connected to the tablet on which I am writing this review - I trust it that much.

It gives me spare juice wherever I need it for my phone and iPads. Sometimes it is more convenient to have my iPad plugged into it while I am in the bed or couch where no wall outlet is nearby. I am also weary of some car chargers ruining my Lightning cables with the inrush current when I start my car ignition (not proven but a hunch), and so I am more comfortable plugging to a battery pack.The 4 LEDs represent the remaining charge from your battery pack. There are 2 white LEDs for use as a flashlight. Two double quick presses to turn it on and off. It alternates from turning on one LED and 2 LEDs in cycle. They are regular LEDs and not the super bright type but still quite welcomed for emergency situations.Overall, it is a fine product though nothing exceptional from other power banks so I am rating it a solid 4 stars.Quick specs:- 10,400 mAh- dual USB slots (One 2.1A for iPad and tablets and one 1A for smartphones)- 2 flashlight LEDs- microUSB charging (cable included)A sample of this product was sent to me for review purposes.

Ten charge and discharge cycles.  Charges over night.  Not sure how long it really takes.  Provides a good emergency battery backup that will take your iPad Retina full size up from 30% to 80% during usage of a little over two hours.I did not try and be as technical with this one as I have with others.  Many of these devices offer up the same charge capability.  So it comes down to how you personally use such things.  If you have two devices to charge you are given a 1A and a 2A.  I did try this with my iPad and my nexus.......it did keep both going even though I drained both to around 20%.  With this I achieved way over an hour of use on both......I have noticed that when left unused it will loose some of it's charge so you will want to plug it in a few hours before you leave to insure full usage.The flashlight is nice.......push the power button twice and on it goes.....nice when trying to find something in your backpack or gadget bag.I was presented with one of these for free.
summary: Capable, multi function, flashlight= a good choice for your portable power needs.

reviewText: I find that many smartphones can not make it through a full day of heavy use without running out of battery. If you work near an outlet this is not an issue but if you are on the go, nothing is worse than a dead phone and no way to recharge. This LifeCharge battery is just the ticket for those needing insurance that they can make it through the day without a dead phone or tablet battery.This unit is rated at 10,400 mAh, which means at five volts it can provide 1 amp of current for ten hours. The bottom line is this is lots of charging capacity. It should be able to fully recharge two dead smartphones, or 1 tablet with power to spare.The unit will charge anything that you would normally charge through a computer USB. It is neat in that it will work for a variety of brands . . . iphones, ipads, droids or windows tablets.I have been pleased with this battery unit.(NOTE: I was provided a sample for review purposes)
summary: Never Get Caught with Dead Phone Again

reviewText: Lifecharge Juicypack 10400 mAH portable charger comes in a very compact design for everyday travel. You can charge two devices at the same time.I tried charging- Samsung Galaxy S4 phones- Samsung Galaxy Tab 4- Olympus Voice Recorder- A 4.5" SmartphoneThe microUSB is used to charge this powerbank and the USB itself to charge other devices. The charge will hold enough to power a Samsung Galaxy S4 nearly 4 times.I tried charging Samsung from no charge to 100% and following is time it took approximately for each of 10 minutes. (using only one port)10% = 7 minutes20% = 7 min30% = 8 min40% = 9 min50% = 11 min60% = 12 min70% = 12 min80% = 14 min90% = 16 min100% = 19 minThis device is great for taking to camping trips/any long distance travel/flight trips and many similar use cases. Sample provided for a fair and honest review.

The Lifecharge Juicepack 10400 mAh charger is fairly typical of its type, with two USB power outlets and MicroUSB charging. In addition to the four, fairly bright charge status lights, it also offers two white LEDs which can illuminate, serving as sort of a flashlight, if you want. They aren't very bright. The manufacturer sent me the charger and asked for a review.Though the USB outlets are labeled as 2A and 1A, I found that they both charged my iPad at about 5 watts (1A), according to my PracticalMeter. A 2.1A wall charger delivered about 7 watts at the same charge level.The Juicypack isn't any larger than it needs to be, and isn't fancy, but it gets the job done, and it has a much larger capacity than most other battery packs.
summary: Lots of capacity, charges two devices at once

reviewText: I received this at no cost in exchange for writing a review. Here are my comments.1. For a such a powerful unit this is light and compact (2 15/16 x 4 1/16 x 3/4 inches). It has two ports (2A and 1A) and a double LED flashlight, which contrary to another review, I think is just as bright as on any other power bank (actually brighter because there are two lights). Just press the power button quickly twice to turn them on and off.A single click of the power button activates the four indicator lights. All four will light up if the unit is full charged, three if it is 3/4 charged etc. A micro USB cable is include for charging, during which the indicator lights go on depending on the charge level, and ultimate all four are on. Contrary to another review, I don't find the indicator lights to be any brighter than on other power banks. If I charge this in a bedroom while I am away I just face the indicator lights toward the wall.2. This does a good job of holding a charge. A week after I fully charged it, all four indicator lights went on when I checked the charge level.3. This easily and effectively charges my iPhone, iPad, Nexus 2013, GoPro camera, etc.4. This is what I now carry in my briefcase along with the included micro USB cable and an Apple cable. Contrary to another review, I'm happy this doesn't have a built in Micro USB cable because power banks that I have like that are not as compact. It's not a big deal for me to stick my cables into the USB ports and wrap them around the unit (no rubber band required for them to stay in place).Bottom line: Perfect for everyday use and travel.

This is a compact way to have 5 ports for charging various devices. The device itself is very compact, measuring only about 4 inches wide and 2.25 inches deep. It has five USB ports on the front. Three are labeled as “universal” ports, and provide a 1A output; two are labeled as “super charger” ports and provide a max of 2.1A. According to the specs, the super charger ports will adjust their output based on the demand of whatever is plugged in. The total output across all five ports is 7.2A/36 watts.It has an on/off switch on the back, which is a feature I really like and is not often found in chargers. I don’t like to leave the charger on overnight, and the switch allows me to turn it off without having to unplug the devices. There’s a small LED indicator on the top that shows when it is powered on. It’s easily visible, but is not lighthouse beacon bright.It has an in-line transformer that is pretty large but, since it’s not at the end of the cord, it doesn't block the wall outlet. The power cord will stretch a good 8 feet, which is great for keeping the charger on my desk but having enough cord slack to plug it into a power strip on the floor.The build quality seems pretty good. All the ports are well anchored; the power cord is sturdy; and the ports are well-labeled with white on black lettering. The only thing it lacks that I would have liked is non-skid feet on the base of the unit. The unit is small and light enough that it’s not a major omission, but it would have been a nice feature to have.Other than the lack of non-skid feet, zero complaints. It’s a simple and compact way to provide 5 usable ports for recharging.[Sample provided for review]
summary: Compact 5-port charger; nice design and build quality

reviewText: This is a 5 in 1 full sized USB wall charger.  That means that you have one unit which will accommodate 5 USB devices.Three of the USB inputs accommodate smaller electronic items that use only 1 amp.  Two of the USB inputs, at the end of the device, accommodate larger amperage consumption electronic items like an iPad or iPhone.  At the back of the device is an ON/OFF switch.  When the product is turned on, a BLUE light will display.The build quality of this product is great, and at the current amazon price - this product is a give away.Based on the good price amazon is selling this product for, I must say that this is a winner.  Just remember that amazon’s prices are violative, and their prices can change daily.~Product received by seller/vendor.If a seller/vendor sends a product, I will not review that product if it falls below 4 stars.  The seller/vendor will be contacted with an explicit explanation as to why the product was rejected for a public review.Understanding star rating:5 stars = I love it.4 stars = I like it.3 stars = It is OK.2 stars = I do not like it.1 star_ = I hate it.

Comdet's very helpful June 5, 2014 review covers most of the characteristics of this charging hub. I want to add a few features that I personally love, and why I awarded my review sample a solid five stars.The first feature that means a lot to me is the extra long power cord assembly. At close to eight feet it stretches from my living room wall to an end table that is a good six feet from the nearest outlet. I am not wild about the transformer part of the power assembly, but on the other hand it keeps the hub itself small.If you do not care about the long power cord feature there are a few more that may be meaningful to you. One that is at the top of my list is this hu has a built in surge protector that prevents it (or devices attached to it) from frying. Where I live this is a big plus because we have electrical issues from storms and the grid itself.Another feature that I like is on two of the ports that are designated as super chargers the is an extra level of protection and intelligence. Each of these ports are for high output devices that draw up to 2.1 Amps of current when being charged. These ports have auto detect circuits that sense the device being charged and adjust accordingly. This prevents overcharging, and also resolves compatibility issues that some devices have. Samsung tablets, in particular, are finicky. I tested these ports with my Samsung Note 3 phone and Tab 3 10.1, as well as an iPad 2 and they worked perfectly.The remaining three ports are generic and put out 1.0 Amps each. I use these to charge the bluetooth speakers and other devices that I seem to accumulate.One final feature is this hub will operate on AC voltages ranging from 100 to 240 volts at 50 or 60 cycles. That means that if you have the proper adapter you can use it in practically any country if you travel.
summary: Excellent features, some of which are very handy for me

reviewText: This little charging station boasts five ports.  Two of the ports are 2.1 amp ports, and the rest are 1 amp ports.  I've used up to four devices at a time - four, because one port is inevitably blocked by a large USB cable head.  Right now, it is busy charging an iPhone, a power bank, a Kindle Fire HD 8.9" tablet, and a 9" Android tablet.  So far, there have been no problems.I like that it can sit on my desk, away from the outlet.  The cord is nice and long, but there is a large AC adapter at the end of it.  It isn't a wall wart which I'm thankful for.  It's more like a floor wart.This product was provided for review by BlueMall.

The EZOPower 5 port 7.2 amp wall charger is one of the most powerful wall chargers I have ever received.Pros:-7.2 amps of output power to the USB’s which is a very high output-5 USB ports (2 of the USB ports are “smart” and can charge any device/tablet at a max of 2.1 amps and the other 3 USB ports have a max output of 1 amp)-Small and portable-Uses a power cable and a power brick to power the wall charger (it is powered by a kind of laptop charging supply)-Has overvoltage, overcurrent, overheating and short circuits protection (built in surge protector in other words)-Can charge an iPad Air, iPad 3, iPhone 5, iPod touch 5 and a Galaxy S4 all at full speed-Works with all USB chargeable phones, tablets and other USB chargeable devices-LED status light that is not annoying-Power on/off button on the back-Ideal for a family/person who has many tablets and smartphones (I have an iPad Air, iPhone 5 and an iPod touch 5 that works great with this wall charger)-UL listed!-Makes an excellent gift-Looks great-Excellent price-Well designed-Good quality constructionCons:-Slides easily-Power brick can be annoyingMy wishes to make this product better:-Add more power so more tablets can charge-Get rid of the power brick-Add grip pads on the bottomThis is a very powerful and well-designed wall charger and I highly recommend it.I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation, for free to keep, and I promised that my review is fair and honest.
summary: Powerful wall charger with 5 powerful USB ports and is UL listed!

reviewText: I've been using these for a couple of weeks and I've been very pleased with the experience. For something to wear while outside, they're the best option I've used.It's not that they have better sound than anything else I've ever tried, or that they're far out ahead in staying in place, or that they have the best safety features, or that their battery life knocks it out of the park, or that they stay out of the way the best, it's that I feel Plantronics did a great job of taking all of the conflicting priorities it takes to make a really good bluetooth headset for outdoor exercise and deciding how to balance them.These are comfortable enough that I rarely think about them once they're on.The sound quality is quite good. It's not as good as options I've tried that are designed to be noise isolated and to sit inside my ear, but those qualities aren't always the priority. I have another bluetooth headset that I sometimes wear and only put one earpiece in, so that I can keep enough of my hearing for basic safety (such as being able to hear when a car is approaching). I can wear these in both ears, and still hear what's going on around me just fine.The pouch that comes with them is nice, and the fact that it can be turned into an armband is an interesting touch, but it's worth noting that it'll mostly only end up holding midsized to smaller devices. For smart phones, I can jam something with a 5" screen in there if I really want to, but it certainly doesn't fit really well, so I prefer to just treat the pouch as a holding pouch.They've been doing a very good job of holding their charge, and I can use them to walk my dog several times before I worry about plugging them in again.These would probably not be my first choice if I were heading to the gym or hopping on the treadmill in my own home (unless I was wanting to make sure that I'd hear easily if someone was talking to me or something on that particular day). I prefer to block out the world a little more when I'm doing those things.I think it's reasonable to assume that these are much safer for older children and teenagers (those who are big enough to wear these, basically) vs headphones that sit inside the ear, since they're not just blasting sound directly at the ear (there are a lot of warnings out there about not letting kids have the headphones that go into the ear, because they tend to turn the volume too high and damage their hearing).When I'm in a situation where I need to be able to hear what's going on, I feel far better going out wearing these than I do in noise-isolating headphones. I've walked around with music playing and have still been able to hear cars, and the air conditioning units on nearby houses as they're running, and dogs when they see me from their yards, and that kind of thing.

I own more headphones than I care to admit.  I currently use a pair of LG Tones that I really like. They are lightweight, sound good and I don't mind the collar.So going into reviewing these that was the baseline.I really like how these stay off my neck.  I never really had a problem with the weight of the LG's but if its hot out or Im exercising, the contact of the collar and my skin is annoying.  These are about half an inch from my head when I wear them.  The skin touching problem is taken care of - but replaced with the bouncing problem.  If I am running I can feel the band in the back of my head moving up and down.  It's also annoying.  So I guess I get to pick which annoyance I want to deal with.Other than that - I really like the sound quality.  They are comfortable to wear, even though the ear buds are a different style (harder plastic) than the LG's (squishy rubber).They paired with my phone very easily.  They look sporty.  The controls are a little annoying to use because of how hard you have to press the button it hurts my ear.  Maybe hurt is too strong - it is momentarily uncomfortable.I have no complaints about them. If I had to choose between these and my LGs I will choose these purely on comfort.

Plantronics BackBeat FIT wireless headphones have accomplished what other wireless headphones couldn't - they fit a small head/ears, are comfortable & stay in place!Syncing to my Windows phone was easy and the sound was clear (I can still hear street noise).  The only problem I had was with the buttons, which are small. I also had a problem with the diagram & labeling, but once I figured out the buttons (the diagram didn't help much), the headphones were easy to use.The case is nice in that it turns inside out to make an armband for my Windows Lumia phone (which stays in place). Charging is pretty quick & the battery life is very good.  I did not try to make/take phone calls, so cannot comment on this feature.Because of the fit, these are my go-to headphones.
summary: Finally, Wireless Headphones that FIT!!!  (small head/ears)

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of Bluetooth headsets for working out.  And I think I've gone through my share of them.  The vast majority don't seem to handle the sweat or the jostling.  Or have a decent battery life.  My current headset has been a Motorola SD-11 which has gone through 2 returns via warranty back to Motorola.  I seem to get about 6 months out of them before they die.  But enough about that.The Plantronics BackBeat FIT were super easy to get opened and get going.  The odd part about these is that the back band is floppy and very light weight.  The charging port is a little bit tricky to find.  You have to use a finger nail to gently slide back the cover.  The nice part though is that the charging light changes color when they're fully charged.Also, the on/off button is slightly tricky the first time.  I am particular about always turning off my headset after a workout to conserve the battery life.Fit is spot on.  These are very light weight and fit just perfectly over my ears.  Because they're so light weight, I don't have a problem wearing them for hours.Sound initially was a problem.  That was because I was in a crowded gym and I had trouble turning the volume up on the BackBeat initially.  I've got the BackBeat volume on high and volume on high on my phone for the most part to block out all background noise.  If I turn down my phone volume, you will still have situation awareness as the headset still lets outside noise in.  I'm comparing this to other headsets where the earpieces go completely in your ear and really block more noise.  These don't go all the way in your ear but pretty close.  I was able to jog outside and still hear cars.Battery has been pretty good thus far.  I've had about 4 or 5 runs in and they're still at "medium".  The battery is only reported as high, medium and low but that is good enough.Overall, these are my new favorite pair.  I'm not sure if the tsunami of sweat that pours from me will eventually kill them but I sure hope not.  I'll update this review should something change.
summary: The Plantronics BackBeat FIT were super easy to get opened and get going

reviewText: I have owned a different pair of BlueTooth ear buds from this brand before that I didn't like at all, but I was very surprised that this pair is great!  This set is NOT noise canceling, but that is on purpose - it's for safety so you can hear you surroundings while exercising outside.  But honestly, the sound is so good, it was ok with me that I can hear my background slightly.  Love the reversible arm band / headphone storage that comes with it!  Nice color, has reflection on it for safety walking, jogging at night!  And it is even roomy enough to hold my iPhone with Otter cover on it!  Comes with charging USB cable - but not a wall outlet (but most don't these days).  I  very pleased with the design!  No tangled cords, fits comfortably in the ears, looks sporty, easy to operate.. What's not to like?!

I've been using these headphones during workouts for about a week and I am very impressed. They are so light and comfortable I don't even notice them, and once you have them on they stay put. I mostly listen to podcasts while exercising, so I can't really speak to the audio quality other than to say it's plenty good enough for me. Other than the relatively high price, I don't have any complaints.

The BackBeat FIT are entirely made of a rubbery, material in a snazzy two-tone matte finish (black and green or black and blue).A built-in loop fits around your ears and holds the earbud in place.The controls are intentionally limited and simple: each earbud features a large round button and a small button right next to it. The benefit is that it's extremely easy to remember: press the left ear to pause or play, the right ear to answer a phone call. Two presses on the left ear to skip to the next track, a long press to go back. A short press on the secondary button on the left ear increases the volume, a continuous press lowers it; a short press on the same button on the right ear reports the battery life remaining, and a long press turns the headset on or off.The FIT charging port is a microUSB connector hidden behind a little hinged cover; charging can take up to 2 1/2 hours if the battery is completely depleted. Plantronics claims a battery life of 8 hours for music playback, 6 hours talk time. In my informal tests, I think it might be closer to 10 hours continuous playback (at reasonable volume). You have a full day of work plus commute and gym time. Nice!The audio quality is excellent. While they're obviously no match for expensive headsets, keep in mind they're exercise headphones meant to withstand lots of sweat and abuse, and they're definitely all the way at the top of that category when it comes to sound.The box contains the headphones, a small manual, a very short USB to microUSB cable (no charger, probably to conform with recent European regulations) and a clever neoprene carry case which can be turned inside out and becomes an armband case.When you first pair the headphones with an iPhone, you are notified that a free Plantronics firmware app is available and asked if you want to download it from the Apple store. I did, and the app told me I needed to upgrade, which I did... and the upgrade failed. Again. And again. That's when I called Plantronics tech support, which determined something was probably wrong and said they would send me a prepaid return label, and ship a replacement as soon as they were notified of the pick up -- amazing service!I then realized I had been using a third party charger (the upgrade process requires the headset to be plugged into a charger and that's what I had handy). Out of curiosity, I used the cable supplied by Plantronics plugged into my monitor's USB port and what do you know... the update completed successfully (I called Plantronics immediately to let them know and cancel the replacement) so if you have the same problem make sure you're using their cable and a quality power adapter.On the iPhone/iPad, a small indicator next to the bluetooth icon in the status bar indicates the remaining power; on Android phones, a free Plantronic app performs the same task. Both apps notify you of available firmware updates.I LIKED------------ Excellent sound quality, and they don't completely cut out all ambient sound- Very limited sound leaks (people around you won't hear what you're listening to)- Convenience -- best gym headphones ever, even better than my go-to LG HBS-730- Bundled neoprene case -- but it's the size of an iPhone 5, good luck sticking a phablet or even a Galaxy S3 into it- Comfort -- they're really pleasant to wear even for extended periods of time- Battery life -- better than the 8 hours advertised- Simple controls- Absolutely stellar customer support.I DISLIKED----------------... nothing. The only slightly irritating thing is that FF/REW is a little tricky to get used to, and good luck doing it while running. On the other hand, it's not like there's that much space on there for buttons, and having only two buttons per side, both very easily identifiable by touch, is a good compromise.In conclusion...If you exercise with music, whether it's running, lifting weights, doing cardio on a treadmill, the FIT are one of the best headphones you can get -- but they're also good enough to be the headphones you wear on public transportation or in your cubicle at work.Very highly recommended.
summary: Good sound, best-in-class battery life, comfortable to wear

reviewText: I was really surprised that this bluetooth headset was as good as it is. It fits my ear fairly well, it stays on 100%, it is easy to locate (nice bright blue) and is very well made. The sound quality on my end has been superb, but I occasionally have complaints from one person that the sound quality is not good for them when I'm talking on this.I can leave it off when I'm driving and it's easy to put on my ears to take a phone call. This charges fast as well and maintains a long battery life. The controls are easy to operate. One of the things I like best about this headset is the ear insert. This is far superior to the same price range single ear bluetooth headsets that have a foam covering that gets lost or a removable plastic ear loop that falls off. This is all in one piece and very high quality. Music sounds amazing as well!I would definitely buy another should I lose this one, and am very pleased in every aspect with this headset.

These are by far the best bluetooth headphones for exercise that I have had!  I have tried the Plantronics Backbeat Go and liked the lightweight/slim design but you had to shove them in your ear to make them fit and then they were uncomfortable after about an hour.  I've also tried the Plantronics Backbeat 903+ and they were more comfortable on your ears but were too loose around the ears and I had to constantly push them back in.These headphones are extremely lightweight, streamlined, and easy to use.  I almost forget that I have them on my head, the sound quality is great, and they connect every time without problems.  I read a couple reviews where they said the strap in the back was irritating on their neck while running but I haven't experienced that at all, I don't even feel the strap.  Overall they are great headphones and I think I can finally stop looking for the right headphones to use when exercising.
summary: These are by far the best bluetooth headphones for exercise that I have had

reviewText: Plantronics has really improved their wireless headphones.  The sound is exceptional and the look is similar to the one's made by Motorola, but these are very functional.  Easy to pair, easy to operate and sufficient wireless time.  Like many popular headphones these offer several ear fitting options.This product is great for the person who wants to advance beyond the wired headphones and is seeking a quality product from a company whose primary business is headphones.

These headphones stay on the head relatively easily, are light and unobtrusive. Bright, reflective color for safety and, well, fun.Sweat and moisture repellent for durability. Includes smartphone armband for workout use.It was hard for me to evaluate the sound because I couldn't get a good fit. The earpieces pushed forward against the inside of my ear, and after a while causes some discomfort. Due to this fit I also couldn't get good sound isolation. However, many reviewers here seem to have gotten it to fit their ears, so maybe it's due to my misshapen head.Assuming you have normal ear canals, it seems these might work for you. I'll be trying them more to see if there are adjustments that will make them work for me.
summary: Depends on how they fit inside your ear

reviewText: These are great headphones.  They connect/pair to my iPhone 5 quickly and easily and fit securely on my head.  I would like them to be just a bit snugger at times, but honestly they have been great during runs and walks.  I've sweated in them and they are still working.  This is huge for me as the last pair of Plantronics bluetooth headphones I had got damage due to my sweat from my intense workouts.  This one so far has lived up to its "waterproof" claim.The controls are easy enough to work.  It took me a bit to figure out that i had to use the little tine nobs/buttons above the round button (yea, I dont like to read the directions), but once I got that figured out, I was all set.  The sound is good, though if the fit was a bit snugger I think I could get some of that high energy music to blast me better.  (yes, I like it loud sometimes when I'm exercising).  I only wear these to exercise with so fit is really important.  The way these go over the ears keeps them on my head and the little piece that holds them in your ear works well too.I have a pair of Jabra bluetooth earbuds too and the sound with those is a little better, but they dont have an over-ear part so I struggle a bit with keeping those one on my head.  If you run or do other high intensity workouts with music, these Plantronics earbuds are a good choice.
summary: Stay put, sweat proof, and decent sound

reviewText: I'm really digging these. This is my fourth set of Bluetooth headphones and my third for workout specific ones.Pairing was super easy and the headphones have good sound. They also have much better battery life than any except my none workout ones. Even better range is at least twice the distance as the least set of Jabra workout specific ones I bought. I also don't have any issues with voice cutting in and out with these.The controls are sparse and easy to use. Sound is good, but nothing Boise like. The ear pieces aren't too bad, but they chafe me after awhile if I 'lock' them in. Unless I'm doing something with a lot of movement like Burpees I just leave them a little lose. I've had this issues with all the in ear plugs like this so its probably just me. The headband around the back for the wires is stiff. Its not annoying but its a bit thicker than I'd prefer, but I'll take it for its toughness.I've also had these puppies out on my beach runs and some water work and they keep chugging along. No issues with water and no issues with salt water specifically. At this point I'd highly recommend them. If I find something else to add, good or bad, then I'll update this. But so far so good.

I have tried many a bluetooth headset. Here's the basics of what Plantronics got right with this one:> Pliable - don't let the photo fool you into thinking this is one of those uncomfortably rigid headsets that you can't rest your head back if you're wearing them. The 'cord' that goes around the back of your head is rubbery and soft. It's firm and holds its shape when it needs to, but it's also bendy and pliable, so you can lay on the sofa or your fave comfy chair while listening to your tunes.> Built for Activity - nice as it is to kick back and enjoy some tunes, BackBeat Fit was built for activity. The rubbery coating ensures these will survive sweaty workouts. Even better, these actually stay in your ears!! Huh; go figure! So many headsets get this flat wrong, and I'm constantly futzing with keeping the buds in my ears. But Plantronics did an exceptional job at designing these to stay in place, where they belong. So do all the jumping, bouncing, running and iron pumping you want, these ain't going anywhere.> Excellent Fit - They're so comfy, I barely even notice I'm wearing them. I love that Plantronics didn't waste any thoughts on the redundancy of extra ear gels. Why? Because they made it right the first time. These ear inserts can be easily rotated and tweaked to fit most any ear comfortably. No extra parts left over, or wondering what to do with them.> Excellent Sound - the audio quality of these are great. They certainly don't compete with top notch over the ear phones, but for buds, the sound is excellent. Rich and deep, though I wish it went just a little bit louder. However, these are much better than any of my Jabras, which are notoriously 3-5db too low in volume, no matter which model you buy.> Easy Controls - just tap for volume up, and hold for volume down. Call and track select buttons all works great too. Love the vocal cues too, alerting to battery level, volume, etc.> Call Quality - stereo headsets aren't always the best for calls. These work fine and people said I sounded good, but I think this feature is best looked at as a convenience. It doesn't compete with the best of the best headsets out there. But for a stereo headset, and the occasional call while jamming or working out, these are one of the better ones I've tried.Bottom Line - fantastic sound, excellent fit, stylish color, velvety feel and volume that should drown out ambient gym noise. These are one of the best athletic bluetooth headsets I've tried. Very nicely done. I'm impressed.

Years ago, when I began my search for a Bluetooth headset I had some specific criteria that has provided to be difficult to fulfill.  Prior to the purchase of the BackBeat FIT headset I've purchased several other brands of various design.All have had their short-comings.  In one area these do, too.  In a noisy environment they do not seal in my ear well enough to overcome the ambient noise regardless of the volume set.  Also, because of the poor seal the bass response is nearly nonexistent.  In a less noisy environment they sound very good although, I'm left wishing for better bass.  If there were a way to improve the seal I'd have no complaints.  My spouse (smaller ears) does not share the same complaint in regard to the seal.  Should you be fortunate enough to have the proper design ear canal you'll be very happy with the comfort and seal of these.My main hope with these were a great improvement in battery life.  No disappoints here.  Depending on the media you can easily obtain the promised run-times.  For instance, audio books will play much longer than highly driven music.  It helps to have the volume on your music player high and adjust the volume on the FIT to your preference.I have a set of Plantronics BackBeat Go 2's to compare.  For me those are perfect except in the run-time department.  If you'd like to save some money I recommend the 2's over the Fits, if you can live with the battery life and troublesome fit some have reported.The Fit's have the most impressive Blue Tooth range of any wireless headset I've ever used.  It really is surprising better.Call quality is very good both receiving and transmitting.  No complaints from any callers at all on either end.They are also very secure.  If these things come out during the normal course of your activities I suspect you'd also be on the way to a hospital.I consider these to be Plantronics best effort and recommend them

Absolutely love them .I've gone through many different wireless headphones this year Sonys, BackBeat Go 2, Motorola SD 11 but this one is amazing great sound even in a loud gym, I workout in a warehouse gym thats always packed and music is turned up to ungodly levels yet the audio on these does not dissapoint.For me they are perfect. Thank you Plantronics.

Plantronics Wireless headphones are truly impressive with their excellent design and quality. The sound quality is exceptional and the fit was perfect for me although it could be too small for some people. The pairing was super easy but the power button was hard to find since it's a tiny black button on the right headphone which is also black. The charger is a USB cable which you can either plug into your computer or hook the USB cable up to your phone wall plug. Again, the design is very sleek and you simply pull a little green tab one of the headphones. It charges fast and the battery lasts a long time. Great product for a great price!

I’ve been sadly behind the times when it comes to wireless headphones for a few reasons: my inner ear is a weird shape that doesn’t fit well with ear buds, and I have big ears. This means that earbuds fall out of my ears and I have a headache after wearing headphones. The Backbeat FIT are the first headphones that stayed on my head and didn’t hurt.There’s so many things these headphones get right. They’re light. They adjust to your ears, bending so that they fit perfectly.  They’re so light that I don’t notice they’re on.  And the stereo quality is fantastic – at least to me, but I’m no audio expert.There are a few flaws, one being the buttons.  You might think that you would turn the headphones on and off by pressing the button on the center of the headphones.  You would be wrong – you actually press the raised edge of one of the buttons. Also, it’s a bright “alien goo” green, but this is really for folks who want to be seen from a distance when the jog (I run on a treadmill).Even the case is awesome.  It turns inside out to be a container for the headphones as well as the charger, and straps neatly around your bicep or leg to hold your iPod.  If you buy one set of headphones, these will do nicely.

These are so much better than I expected, honestly.  First off - looking at the photos I thought the neck band would be stiff, but it's not! It's super soft and wraps nicely around my head.  Honestly, I fell asleep with these on laying on my back!The sound is AMAZING for how they are shaped.  I thought for sure they would sound strange because of the way the ears are shaped, but they are so crystal clear and make my music sound even better.They're really easy to use. Just hold down the button to turn it on and then use the little buttons on the ears to make it go.  There are these little black tabs on each ear to help you identify which ear does what.  I found this very useful.The battery life exceeded the stated 8 hours of music play. I fell asleep for about 9 hours and woke up with them still playing from a full charge.These headphones have changed my life. In fact, I am now selling my Bose headphones on eBay because I love these so much.  They are so soft!
summary: So much softer than I expected - very comfortable and the sound is crystal clear!

reviewText: I am a runner, gym patron, and longtime Plantronics bluetooth customer: I've had several 903+'s and a Go 2.  The Go 2 doesn't stay in my ears and is on the large side for exercising, but it seemed like the best thing available last year.The Fit is disappointing in three ways: 1)  It's not loud enough, 2) the ear pieces hurt my ears due to their hardness, and 3) the phone functionality is the worst of the Plantronics I've had, and the call quality isn't very good with the other Plantronics headphones I mentioned above.1) Not loud enough -- The is a big problem.  I like to download movies to my Note 3 and watch them in the gym as I work out.  These movies typically play more quietly than other videos.  The Go 2 plays the movies just loud enough for me to hear and enjoy them in my noisy gym.  The Fit plays the very same movies just quietly enough that I can't hear them in the gym.  Music and other videos that play louder sound excellent.I have a speakerboost application that doesn't seem to make any difference to the Fit volume, but they have a feature that Plantronics should use.  Namely, they only boost to 60% unless you go into settings and allow them to boost more, which requires acknowledging that you are making this change.  If Plantronics is so worried about lawsuits if they make the headphones loud enough to hear in noisy places, they should use this feature to allow people to choose a higher volume.2)  The Fit doesn't fit --  The Fit earphones do stay in place no matter what I do.  I think it may also be possible to find positions for each ear that don't hurt, but so far, I have either failed to achieve that or I may have succeeded once.  They take me a lot of fiddling with them to try to find a position that won't hurt.Why it would have been so hard to make the earpieces softer is anyone's guess.3)  Call quality is bad -- I've made five calls with the Fit.  Three were so bad on both ends, it was almost pointless.  Two were good on both ends.  The three that were bad were with the same person, someone with whom I had spoken on the Go 2 as well.  On the Go 2, the other party sounded fine but complained about background noise.  With the Fit, both sides break up terribly and the person on other side hated the noise far worse than with the Go 2.It's nice to have earphones that stay in place--I bought a pair of wired earphones 7 years ago for under $5.00 that had an over-the-ear component that kept them in place, but they weren't waterproof.  It's nice that in 2014 Plantronics had the breakthrough of waterproof earphones that stay in place.  Now if I could only hear them without ear pain and make calls, they'd be perfect.  Perhaps Plantronics will resolve one of these issues next year and soak me for another $150, then resolve another one in the following year for, say, $180, and maybe they can do the last one in three years for, say, $210.UPDATE:  I exchanged my pair in hopes that my complaints were particular to the unit I received.  The connecting chord in back on the new one is slightly longer, within a margin of manufacturing error.  With the new one, I can get a more or less comfortable fit.  Unfortunately, the volume level and call quality are precisely the same.

Well, it took a little time to get used to both the fit AND and the interface, but I finally feel ready to properly review the Plantronics Backbeat Fit headphones. Previously, I have been using the Jaybird Bluebuds X. As many reviewers of the Jaybirds have indicated, they are pretty nice earphones that sound more than acceptable when inserted correctly. But, I've had a lot of issues getting them to stay in my ears despite trying many of the varying adapters and different-sized earbuds. Unfortunately, if a good seal isn't maintained, the sound quality of the Jaybirds deteriorates dramatically. Lastly, I don't really love the the long neck strap/cord on the Jaybirds. It bounces around regardless of whether place in front of or behind my neck, or even inside my shirt. I tried the cord fasteners but they didn't really resolve the bouncing issue.So, that brings me to my quest for an alternative. Enter the Plantronics Backbeat Fit. Let's get right down to it....FORMThe entire headset (note, they are not earphones) is molded from a very flexible, rubbery material. It looks exceedingly durable and is nicely accented with reflective blue to aid visibility while running while dark out. The Backbeats are a little tricky to put on, though, because the ear supports are somewhat snug and I found it difficult to get them on around my ears. Who knows, perhaps I have bigger ears. However, after doing it a few times, it got easier and I can now throw them on and off without thinking about it. Moreover, the headset stays comfortably in place while exercising (running, lifting, etc). The individual earpieces also have a small rubber wire that's used to help keep the speaker snug next to the auditory canal. It's not sealed as with earphones but it keeps the speaker close. Plantronics indicates that the design was chosen in order to allow some outside noise (sirens, people yelling, horns, etc) to be heard while listening to music, thus reducing the risks of an accident while out and about. All in all, it's a very handsome design and I likeFITAs noted above, the headset stays in place well and has been very comfortable for the several times that I've worn them. The previously mentioned over-the-ear supports and canal wire stays definitely help to keep them in place while running around. It's something that I could not say about the Jaybird earphones. Moreover, because there is no loose support cord bouncing around, I really felt completely free while listening to my music. It's a cool experience and I like that I don't have to constantly adjust the headset while on the go.SOUNDHere's the million dollar question: how do they sound? I guess they are alright. But first, let me preface that after years of listening to in-earphones, I'm pretty spoiled by what headphones should sound like. The key, though, is that earphones only sound excellent when a solid seal is maintained. In all my years of using them while exercising, I've never been able to achieve that because of either sweat or poor fit despite trying numerous earbuds. Also, I will admit that a fully sealed earphone leaves one pretty isolated from traffic and people around me. The Plantronics take a different approach. They have gone with a headset that lets some sound in for safety. In the process, the sound is somewhat diminished. To compensate, the highs and very lows have been boosted pretty aggressively (almost obscenely, candidly). Since it's a headset, however, it's not too bad unless the earpiece sits very close to the canal. At that point, the harsh treble and overly explosive bass become annoying. Curiously, the upper bass and midrange suffer a bit. They sound a hint flat and quite lackluster since they are overshadowed by low bass and treble. While the Backbeats are NOT what I'd want for my walk-around or at-home listening pleasure, they are perfectly adequate for exercise. First, they stay in place exactly where I put them. It's a relief to go for a run or lift weights and not have to constantly adjust the headset for a better fit and accordingly, better sound. The Plantronics just stay consistently average and acceptable...which is MORE than fine for their purpose. So, while the sound isn't the best, it's works well for its state use...and for that I'm greatly and finally relieved.OTHER FEATURESWhile I don't use the telephone functions much, I'll state that they work very well. Calls from my wife never resulted in any complaints other than that fact that she said I sounded like I was breathing heavily. I indicated that I was breathing heavily since I was running. So, the mic quality is clearly good enough to pick that up. For my part, call quality on my end was quite good and without any major or minor complaints.The controls, on the other hand, are a bit tricky. While calls and music are easily operated (calls are easily answered and ended by tapping on the right earpiece; music play and pause is controled by tapping on the left earpiece). Nevertheless, it turns out that Plantronics made a quirky design decision with the volume, skip and power buttons. On the top of the round central buttons used for calls and music are much smaller 'ledges' that are used. This was not intuitive out of the box; indeed, I struggled for quite a bit trying to find out how to power the headset on. The right upper button 'ledge' is tilted/pressed down in order to power them on and off. Trying to describe it better, it's not the round button center that is pressed, but the top 'edge' or 'ledge' of the button that is pressed/tilted to activate these other features. It's simple after you do it once (indeed, I felt like an idiot for not noticing it sooner), but I thought to highlight it for people who have had similar issues. Meanwhile, the left 'ledge' is used to control volume (click once for louder, hold down for quieter). And that's it, you should be good to go.FINAL THOUGHTSSo, are these the greatest headphones? No. But, for exercise, they sure come close. would I like them to sound better? Yes. But, if it comes at the cost of having to constantly adjust and insert/reinsert earbuds, then No. While I started off thinking I wouldn't really love the Backbeat Fit because it wasn't an earphone design, I've been pleasantly surprised because of how well they do what they are supposed to do (once you figure out the interface). And for that, I'm giving them 4 stars. I know some will criticize because of the sound quality, but for what I use them for and for how well they stay snugly in place, the music is good enough for what I need them to do.
summary: A good headset with acceptable sound that stays in place during workouts

reviewText: Fit and sound are great. Best BT in-ear headphones I've found thus far, and I've tried them all. Big improvement over the 903+. The only negative is the arm band. Clearly, Plantronics was catering to the iPhone folks because my Galaxy S5 will not fit. So when the iPhone 6 comes out with a larger screen, they'll have the same issue. Dumb.

These lightweight headphones are easy to pair with mobile music device. Sound quality is very good and they do not completely block the outside noise so you can still hear the traffic. They sit on the ears and do not go all the way in. Controls are easily accessible. Also nice is that you can see remaining battery life on iPhone. Generally they can tolerate the exercise movement well  and stay in the ears although may require some adjustment during prolonged exercise.The cons that I can find are that they are relatively expensive, and after using them for a while, they become uncomfortable to wear. And if you exercise on a treadmill at home and want to completely block the outside sound then they are not for you.So they are primarily outdoor exercise headphones.

I have the Backbeat Go and love those, which is why I got these for my wife and since the in-ear only buds don't work well for her.  Part of the reason I got these was because the storage case/arm band is a great idea and BUT it's obvious they designed the dimensions with an iPhone 5/5s in mind (they even have a picture of an iPhone in the case on the back of the box), problem with that is many other popular phones are bigger and the next iPhone out in 3-4 months will be too, so that basically makes the arm band useless if it doesn't fit.  No foresight by releasing a product designed around another product at the end of it's life cycle.  More later on sound and battery life, but expect both to be on par or better than the Go model.

Over the years I've tried a lot of different Bluetooth headphones for running and have always been pretty disappointed.  Some would lose their connection, others were bulky, and a couple sets stopped working after just a few months.  I'd always end up going back to a cheap pair of wired headphones because Bluetooth just didn't seem to be ready for running the the hot Texas sun for an hour a day on an excessive sweater.These headphones might be the first that will prove to be a permanent replacement for my wired headphones.  They are light-weight, sound great, remain connected, and so far seem to be very durable and water proof.  They work great for calls, sound wonderful with music, were easy to connect to my Nexus 5 phone, and are super-simple to operate.I have no complaints and am very glad to finally have some wireless workout headphones that aren't more hassle than they are worth.
summary: The best Bluetooth Headphones so far for running

reviewText: I need to start out with I'm not a fan of headphones in my ear.  These were tolerably uncomfortable in the ear  Around the ear was great, and I've had reconstructive surgery on one ear after cancer surgery.  It's a bit misshapen.So, why the 4 star and not lower? The sound quality was great. Pairing to my android phone, ipad, and ipod was extremely easy.  Ease of use on a call was too easy.I purchased this for when I work at home. I easily got 8 hours of listen/talk time. And, I listened to music when I was not on a call. Talk was clear on both sides of the discussion.I just wish the were more comfortable in the ear.
summary: Love the sound quality. Wish the in ear fit was more comfortable

reviewText: Had the original Plantronics Backbeat for almost 5 years. They finally ran their course & had to be replaced. Since the majority of the time I used my old ones for running, these FIT headphones made the most sense. They had rave reviews on Amazon & I was very excited to get them in my ears! I am sad to say I was let down...The design is very poor. My previous Backbeat's had rubber buds that are very flexible & adjust to the ear canal quite easily; these have the antithesis.  Extremely hard buds with little rubber movement caused an uncomfortable fit in my ear, especially in my right ear which (I am now finding out) has a deeper canal than my left. I never noticed this in my previous headphones because the bud was rubber & easily adjustable. Because these buds on the FIT are hard, the sound quality is different in each ear, which is super annoying.The sound, in general, is fine but again, because of the poor design, I could never have the full listening potential I want, as they do not sit right in my ears.I cannot explain how excited I was for these; if they were just like the original Plantronics but with an athletic twist to them, 5 stars would be given right now...instead, I have to blast the design & return them today; I would get the 903+, but I already purchased them months ago & had to return them due to the poor range on Bluetooth, compared to the original ones I have been using for years. You will notice a bunch of people say the same thing on the 903+ with the range being horrible & almost unusable.Truly disappointed.
